content.content: Hi Everyone, As most of you know, we had an informal poll to have a cool off period before we decided what to do with the 84k MKR received from the Foundation. While months have not passed, I think enough time has gone by that we can make certain decisions about these funds. I would personally like to propose that we send these funds to the burner. Pros  Removes the cognitive overhead of deciding what to do with these funds. Trying to find a “purpose” for these funds will ultimately lead to potential wasteful spending. Potential positive PR implications  Cons  Potential legal ramifications with regards to securities law when minting future MKR to replace burned ones Could be used in the future for fundraising or any unforseen capital costs. Counter-argument is minting would achieve the same goal (loop back to possible legal ramifications)  Should we burn the 84,000 MKR sent to us from the Foundation?     Yes No Abstain     0 voters     Next Steps Polling will end on 2021-06-10T16:00:00Z. If “Yes” wins with a majority, I will create an on-chain poll for MKR holders to vote on the following Monday. If “Yes” then passes the on-chain poll, an executive in the future will be created that includes a spell that will burn this MKR. As always, I look forward to hearing your feedback and discussion.

content.content: I voted no because I believe future mints will have a much more negative PR impact. The funds were already taken out of circulating supply when they were sent to the PauseProxy. We’ve seen how the market does not care at all about FDV, so I believe the potential positive PR impact of a large burn of funds outside the circulating supply is minimal at this point – especially if we instead introduce a meme of uncertainty about future mints on an ongoing basis, which we know will happen instead as Core Units start to vest MKR. Having what can be perceived as a treasury I’d argue makes Maker seem less risky, and that has its positive PR implications as well. Furthermore, the community already has to make tough decisions regarding spending of surplus, so saying that there’s a risk of inefficient spending or cognitive overhead is not a risk that applies only to the MKR in the PauseProxy, but to the project in general. MKR can be minted and inefficiently spent by the community as well, so I’m not sure I follow the argument here. Another point is that these funds actually provide flexibility as we can potentially avoid future ideological debates and contentious gridlocks around MKR minting in the community by keeping this stack of funds around. I do not think minting MKR for rewards or other opportunities in general is a topic that has been fully debated yet, so burning these funds without a proper understanding of the community sentiment regarding minting-at-will (which would be the direct consequence of burning the funds) might just put us on a path of future problems. Therefore I argue that we should keep the MKR for now so we can at least cover the costs we know are coming, which are the CU incentives, and trust that the governance processes are strong enough to properly handle the remaining funds.

content.content: I voted NO, we should not burn MKR. We should fund companies that help us set up and develop an only Dai ecosystem

So it did occur to me that while this functionally doesn’t make a huge difference, it does have some minor accounting implications. If these are not burned, it does mean that from an accounting standpoint, total equity is reduced to account for the fact these tokens no longer circulate but are still outstanding. This should not come as a surprise as price*total MKR tokens = market cap is clearly not the actual equity of MKR holders until you subtract the 84,000 tokens held in treasury. Whereas, if they are burned – and actually all of the burning Maker has done to date – needs to be accounted for in one of several different methods. I suspect this is a massive headache for whomever has the unenviable task of trying to make a guesstimate balance sheet for Maker, since some of the methods require knowing what the original paid-in capital was (the original sale price of the tokens). I suspect we have not been tracking this (I’m not sure how you could without access to the Foundation’s books), so were I the person in charge of that, I’d probably prefer that the 84,000 not be burned, simply because it represents a significant amount of the tokens outstanding, and the number already burned are small enough to (with a footnote or other disclosure) ignore until we can really try to sit down with the Foundation and get all the information they have on their books to figure out what the paid-in capital was on original and BT token issuance to be. It’s pretty simple to deduct the 84,000 from equity, but likely a bit of an information hunt to coordinate with the Foundation (or maybe we don’t, since I’m not sure what happens when transferring contra equity to a successor entity?) how these would affect retained earnings or paid-in capital.
